repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4280

@scoder @matusvalo before adding more tests here, I wanted to ask if this was the high level approach you had in mind and if the implementation looks OK to you.

comment_data.body: Redundant line
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_val = None

comment_data.body:
This line can now be removed (similar below).

In contrast, the `except -1` case (i.e. the as-of-now still non-existent else-branch of `if s.sy == '?'`) will need an `exc_check = 0`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_val = None
+        exc_check = 0
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
             exc_check = 1

comment_data.body: Not sure this is correct; before we weren't looking for `s.sy == 'IDENT'` preceding an `except`; the placement of `noexcept` is the same, why the need to also check `'IDENT'`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':

comment_data.body: Thanks! I might be missing something, but I just borrowed from other parts of the parser that parse out other C/C++/Cython symbols. They all seem to do checks like `s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'cppclass'`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':

comment_data.body: Could you please help me understand what it means when `exc_val != None` but `exc_check = 0`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_val = None
+        exc_check = 0
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
             exc_check = 1

comment_data.body:
Without having checked in detail, this looks right to me.

It's 'IDENT' because it isn't specifically a reserved keyword (because you should be able to use `noexcept` as a Python variable name for example). You check for that, then you check the content. If you didn't check for `IDENT` first then I don't know if you'd be confident it has a `systring` attribute.

Not completely sure of any of this but it definitely looks reasonable on a first look.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':

comment_data.body: The difference is that `except` is a Python keyword, so gets picked out as special at an earlier stage...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':

comment_data.body: That makes total sense -- thanks!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':

comment_data.body: Aside from just keeping parity with the way the values are set currently (my starting point for the comments I made), you can check out the difference in the [docs](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html#error-return-values) between `except? -1` (checked)  and `except -1` (unchecked).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_val = None
+        exc_check = 0
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
             exc_check = 1

comment_data.body:
Ah thanks -- I was misunderstanding what `exc_check = False` implied. I thought it meant no check is done at all.

It looks like if `exc_val != None`, then a check is done if the return value is `exc_val`, even if `exc_check = 0`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
         return 0
 
 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_val = None
+        exc_check = 0
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
             exc_check = 1

comment_data.body: Is this used?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,4 +56,29 @@ def test_except_promotion_compare(bint fire):
     ...
     RuntimeError
     """
-    except_promotion_compare(fire)
\ No newline at end of file
+    except_promotion_compare(fire)
+
+
+cdef int cdef_function_that_raises():
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int cdef_function_that_raises_noexcept() noexcept:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+def test_except_raise_by_default():
+    """
+    >>> test_except_raise_by_default()
+    Traceback (most recent call last):
+    ...
+    RuntimeError
+    """
+    cdef_function_that_raises()
+
+def test_noexcept():
+    """
+    >>> test_noexcept()
+    """
+    cdef_function_that_raises_noexcept()
+
+
+cdef int return_value

comment_data.body: Has there been some further discussion on consistent vs. less-breaking? By my count there wasn't a strong direction either way (both in this PR and the issue), but perhaps slightly in favour of consistency (i.e. default is to always check, also for extern functions)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,17 +3009,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
-    # the default behaviour is to always
-    # check for exceptions
-    exc_check = 1
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = 0
+    else:
+        exc_check = 1

comment_data.body: Sorry -- I was really just experimenting here and trying to get tests to pass before making further progress either ways :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,17 +3009,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
-    # the default behaviour is to always
-    # check for exceptions
-    exc_check = 1
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = 0
+    else:
+        exc_check = 1

comment_data.body: This was decided now in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4280#issuecomment-1100588580
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,17 +3009,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
-    # the default behaviour is to always
-    # check for exceptions
-    exc_check = 1
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = 0
+    else:
+        exc_check = 1

comment_data.body: BTW, I think we can start using `True` and `False` here. They have been part of Python for about 20 years now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,10 +3009,17 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = 0
+    else:
+        exc_check = 1

comment_data.body:
I'm not sure if we should really remove this, or just keep it as an explicit marker. Wouldn't hurt to have it, would it?

Also, we need to add `noexcept` to this output now, if no exception check is enabled and the return type is a C type.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3119,9 +3119,6 @@ def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
                 trailer = " except %s" % self.exception_value
             elif self.exception_check == '+':
                 trailer = " except +"
-            elif self.exception_check and for_display:
-                # not spelled out by default, unless for human eyes
-                trailer = " except *"

comment_data.body: I just noticed that it's apparently `noexcept with gil` but `nogil noexcept`. I think we should keep the order the same and be strict. It doesn't help users to allow both.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@ def test_parallel():
 
     free(buf)
 
-cdef int get_num_threads() with gil:
+cdef int get_num_threads() noexcept with gil:

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                    #   the signature must match the base type signature.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -730,8 +730,11 @@ def analyse(self, return_type, env, nonempty=0, directive_locals=None, visibilit
                 # Even if it is not declared, we can use the default exception value of the return type,
                 # unless the function is some kind of external function that we do not control.
                 if return_type.exception_value is not None and (visibility != 'extern' and not in_pxd):
-                    # Extension types are more difficult because the signature must match the base type signature.
-                    if not env.is_c_class_scope:
+                    # - We skip this optimization for extension types; they are more difficult because
+                    #   the signature match the base type signature.

comment_data.body: Trailing space
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1173,7 +1173,7 @@ cdef void copy_strided_to_strided({{memviewslice_name}} *src,
                              src.shape, dst.shape, ndim, itemsize)
 
 @cname('__pyx_memoryview_slice_get_size')
-cdef Py_ssize_t slice_get_size({{memviewslice_name}} *src, int ndim) nogil:
+cdef Py_ssize_t slice_get_size({{memviewslice_name}} *src, int ndim) nogil noexcept:

comment_data.body: Ah yeah sorry - I added this back. Turns out what really needed changing was the test code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3119,9 +3119,6 @@ def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
                 trailer = " except %s" % self.exception_value
             elif self.exception_check == '+':
                 trailer = " except +"
-            elif self.exception_check and for_display:
-                # not spelled out by default, unless for human eyes
-                trailer = " except *"

comment_data.body:
I believe it's also `except -1 with gil` but `nogil except -1`, for instance, so the current placement of `noexcept` is consistent with that.

Do we want to change this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@ def test_parallel():
 
     free(buf)
 
-cdef int get_num_threads() with gil:
+cdef int get_num_threads() noexcept with gil:

comment_data.body:
Counts as deliberate breakage, I guess. I think the way forward is then to allow both placements for one(!) of the two modifiers already in 0.29.x, and then deprecate one of them by first making the documentation consistent.

Since `with gil`reads best at the end of the signature line (because it's similar to a `with gil:` statement inside of the function), I think we should allow `except -1 nogil`, and then newly require `noexcept nogil`, so that people get used to that order.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@ def test_parallel():
 
     free(buf)
 
-cdef int get_num_threads() with gil:
+cdef int get_num_threads() noexcept with gil:

comment_data.body: Spurious indent here

@scoder re: your comment [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4670#discussion_r854489596), I believe this will allow placing `nogil` either before or after the exception value -- was this what you were looking for?

If we want to enable this only for Cython < 3.0, would parsing `Cython.__version__` be the right way to go about that? (I couldn't find similar examples in the codebase).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2899,7 +2899,8 @@ def p_c_func_declarator(s, pos, ctx, base, cmethod_flag):
     ellipsis = p_optional_ellipsis(s)
     s.expect(')')
     nogil = p_nogil(s)
-    exc_val, exc_check = p_exception_value_clause(s)
+    exc_val, exc_check = p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx)
+    nogil = nogil or p_nogil(s)

comment_data.body:
Based on this [discussion](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4670/files#r854489596), this should probably be:
```suggestion
cdef int write_unraisable() noexcept nogil:
```
(and same below several times)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ def test_nogil_exception_propagation():
         nogil_func()
 
 
-cdef int write_unraisable() nogil:
+cdef int write_unraisable() nogil noexcept:

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
cdef int cdef_noexcept_function_that_raises() noexcept:
    raise RuntimeError
```
IMO clearer / less ambiguous naming of the intent...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,4 +56,26 @@ def test_except_promotion_compare(bint fire):
     ...
     RuntimeError
     """
-    except_promotion_compare(fire)
\ No newline at end of file
+    except_promotion_compare(fire)
+
+
+cdef int cdef_function_that_raises():
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int cdef_function_that_raises_noexcept() noexcept:
+    raise RuntimeError

comment_data.body:
I think it's confusing that the values for `exc_check` can take `True/False/'+'`. 

`CFuncType` says this is a boolean member,
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/9341e73aceface39dd7b48bf46b3f376cde33296/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L2853-L2858

but that's not true, it's used at least here
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/9341e73aceface39dd7b48bf46b3f376cde33296/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L2988-L2992

and here
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/9341e73aceface39dd7b48bf46b3f376cde33296/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L3041-L3045
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,13 +3010,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = False
+    else:
+        exc_check = True
+
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_check = False
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
-            exc_check = 1
+            exc_check = True
             s.next()
         elif s.sy == '+':
             exc_check = '+'

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            else:
                exc_check = False
            # exc_val can be non-None even if exc_check is False, c.f. "except -1"
            exc_val = p_test(s)
```
Maybe a comment could be helpful here?  I ended up getting caught out again by the same [misapprehension](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4670#discussion_r817205131) that @shwina had in March, namely that it would be impossible to have `exc_check is False and exc_val is not None`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3029,8 +3037,10 @@ def p_exception_value_clause(s):
                 s.next()
         else:
             if s.sy == '?':
-                exc_check = 1
+                exc_check = True
                 s.next()
+            else:
+                exc_check = False
             exc_val = p_test(s)

@@ -3130,7 +3130,9 @@ def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
             arg_decl_code = "void"
         trailer = ""
         if (pyrex or for_display) and not self.return_type.is_pyobject:
-            if self.exception_value and self.exception_check:
+            if not self.exception_check and not self.exception_value:
+                trailer = " noexcept"
+            elif self.exception_value and self.exception_check:
                 trailer = " except? %s" % self.exception_value
             elif self.exception_value:
                 trailer = " except %s" % self.exception_value

comment_data.body:
My 2c is that semantically `except +` is not the same as `exc_check=False, exc_val=True` (`except *` for example is also not associated with a particular exception value).

I agree that the three-value state is undesirable. Do you think this can be tackled in a separate PR instead?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,13 +3010,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = False
+    else:
+        exc_check = True
+
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_check = False
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
-            exc_check = 1
+            exc_check = True
             s.next()
         elif s.sy == '+':
             exc_check = '+'

comment_data.body: Apologies for not making this clearer, but taking over these two lines was equivalent to mapping `exc_val == '+'` to `exc_check=False, exc_val=True`. So unless/until you do that, you'll need to remove these two lines again.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3132,8 +3132,12 @@ def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
         if (pyrex or for_display) and not self.return_type.is_pyobject:
             if self.exception_value and self.exception_check:
                 trailer = " except? %s" % self.exception_value
-            elif self.exception_value:
+            elif self.exception_value and not self.exception_check:
                 trailer = " except %s" % self.exception_value
+            elif not self.exception_value and self.exception_check:
+                trailer = " except +"

comment_data.body:
typo sneaking in
```suggestion
cdef int cdef_noexcept_function_that_raises() noexcept:
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,4 +56,26 @@ def test_except_promotion_compare(bint fire):
     ...
     RuntimeError
     """
-    except_promotion_compare(fire)
\ No newline at end of file
+    except_promotion_compare(fire)
+
+
+cdef int cdef_function_that_raises():
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int cdef_noexcept_-function_that_raises() noexcept:

comment_data.body: I don't want to overload this PR, but my thinking was that it's already touching a lot of things about this (changing the default, transforming to bool). I'll defer to Stefan or David whether it's a good idea to do it here, but equally happy to try it in a follow-up, if removing the tristate as suggested is pronounced desirable at all.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,13 +3010,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = False
+    else:
+        exc_check = True
+
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_check = False
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
-            exc_check = 1
+            exc_check = True
             s.next()
         elif s.sy == '+':
             exc_check = '+'

comment_data.body: My view is probably "tri-state isn't great but should probably be done in a follow up".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3009,13 +3010,20 @@ def p_with_gil(s):
     else:
         return 0
 
-def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':
+    if ctx.visibility  == 'extern':
+        exc_check = False
+    else:
+        exc_check = True
+
+    if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'noexcept':
+        s.next()
+        exc_check = False
+    elif s.sy == 'except':
         s.next()
         if s.sy == '*':
-            exc_check = 1
+            exc_check = True
             s.next()
         elif s.sy == '+':
             exc_check = '+'

comment_data.body:
In terms of Cython <3.0 you'd make a separate PR against the 0.29.x branch with just this change and whatever tests were needed.

I wasn't sure from the comment when it'd be deprecated, but I'd imagine it'd probably have to be allowed in Cython 3 initially. I wouldn't parse `Cython.__version__`, just commit different code to the two branches
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2899,7 +2899,8 @@ def p_c_func_declarator(s, pos, ctx, base, cmethod_flag):
     ellipsis = p_optional_ellipsis(s)
     s.expect(')')
     nogil = p_nogil(s)
-    exc_val, exc_check = p_exception_value_clause(s)
+    exc_val, exc_check = p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx)
+    nogil = nogil or p_nogil(s)

commit.message: Change the default behavior to always check for exceptions
Don't check for exceptions if `except -1` form used
Merge branch 'propagate-exceptions-by-default' of github.com:shwina/cython into propagate-exceptions-by-default
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/cython/cython into propagate-exceptions-by-default
Don't check for exceptions if except -1 form used
Add a bunch of noexcepts to MemoryView.pyx

Revert "Add a bunch of noexcepts to MemoryView.pyx"

This reverts commit e09fc5eb982832b49c2446e3fb7a260fb2aee2fd.
Skip exception value optimization for function pointers
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/cython/cython into propagate-exceptions-by-default
For extern functions, keep the previous default behaviour
Now include the exception value in the expected type
Add new argument to function declaration
Add noexcept to alloc_callback and dealloc_callback
Allow placing nogil before or after exception value
Merge branch 'propagate-exceptions-by-default' of github.com:shwina/cython into propagate-exceptions-by-default
Change  the  expected  output to include noexcept
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:cython/cython into propagate-exceptions-by-default

verification.payload:
tree b9782f051783a3619e29fba32c8775d02ea255ba
parent 7a068b9ad1e073120e155fc5d0d11d683a194d2f
author Ashwin Srinath <3190405+shwina@users.noreply.github.com> 1655992831 -0400
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1655992831 -0400
